data.title: Berlin's best lakes for sunbathing and wild swimming
data.meta_description: The German capital is home to some 80 lakes – just right for keeping cool in summer, says Zoe Strimpel
data.text:
A trip to a Berlin lake is a uniquely refreshing, soul-enhancing thing – and it’s also what keeps Berliners in the city during what can be very hot summers. Here are six of my favourites:

Müggelsee

Located in the far east of the city, the Müggelsee (also known as the Grosser Müggelsee) covers 7.4 sq km, making it the largest of Berlin’s lakes. It has a wild and sandy edge, with wooded walkways; a party boat that rocks with dance beats as it steams from shore to shore; a lakeside sauna; and a massive strandbad with “FKK” section for those wanting to sunbathe in the nude.

• The best hotels in Berlin

On a hot summer’s day, find yourself a bit of shady sand by a tree, lay out your towel among the picnickers and wade on in. This lake is good for those who aren’t confident swimmers as the first 100 metres are only thigh-deep; eventually, though, it turns into a deep, clear, cold and sometimes fast-flowing body of water.

Details

Fürstenwalder Damm 838, Treptow-Köpenick. Take the S3 from Ostkreuz to Friedrichshagen, then walk about 25 minutes down Bölschestrasse and Müggelseedamm (or cut through the woods) to the lake perimeter. Alternatively, take the seven-minute tram ride between Friedrichshagen S-Bahn and Müggelsee Strandbad. Entrance: free.

• German tourists: 'arrogant, boring and nude'

Schlachtensee

Located in the far west of the city, the Schlachtensee is the southernmost of the chain of lakes surrounding the Grunewald (Green Forest) and is one of the most picturesque (for its kidney shape), celebrated for the high quality of its silky, cooling water.

The Schlachtensee is the southernmost of the chain of lakes surrounding the Grunewald Photo: AP/FOTOLIA

It is easy to get to – just seconds’ walk from the S-bahn stop named after it – and it has a party vibe. Most people sunbathe on a green, which starts with a large flat section over the road from the S-bahn station and leads (quite steeply) down to the water, though many also head for the lake’s s lush perimeter with its selection of shaded micro-beaches. But the slope is a more reliable suntrap and has a jaunty atmosphere, thanks to a combination of boisterous teenagers, solo novel-readers, parent-toddler outings, and chatting girlfriends. There’s no strandbad with shops and cafés, so people tend to buy beers, sausages, chips and ice cream from Seestern, and a biergarten.

Details

Am Schlachtensee, Steglitz-Zehlendorf. Take the S1 to Schlachtensee (30 minutes from Potsdamer Platz). Entrance: free.

Plötzensee

An odd but delightful little lake, Plötzensee – which shares its name with the nearby prison – was bought from a Spandau monastery by the city of Berlin in 1817, and its banks have been used ever since for a range of recreational activities.

• 18 unusual things one can see in Germany

German football fans celebrate in the Plötzensee Photo: ALAMY

It is very central and curiously quiet on weekdays, particularly if you go early. Here, too, you can find snack bars and terraces; a playground on the beach; hefty beach chairs complete with sun-shielding hoods; and a beach for nudists. The only catch is that the lake isn’t the clearest: by mid-July the water goes a bit green and murky, though it maintains high health and safety standards for swimming.

Details

Nordhaven 26, Wedding. Take the S-bahn to Westhafen or Beusselstrasse. Entrance: €4.

Krumme Lanke

Possibly the most idyllic lake in Berlin, Krumme Lanke is on the edge of the Grunewald forest and served by its own U-Bahn station. Its undulating banks are framed by tall willow trees and healthy marshes. Thanks to its curvy shape, it has numerous sunbathing nooks, from sandy beaches staggered over log steps, to numerous smaller bays.

Krumme Lanke is on the edge of the Grunewald forest and served by its own U-Bahn station Photo: AP/FOTOLIA

The lake attracts a fairly boisterous crowd in summer, including the students of the nearby Freie Universität, as well as families. The main beach has some changing facilities and an imbiss (snack hut), but this is a place to bring a picnic.

Details

Grunewald. Take the U3 to Krumme Lanke. Entrance: free.

Wannsee

The best-known lake in Berlin, this enormous, yacht-club-rimmed expanse of water occupies a prime spot in the far western part of the city and is actually closer to Potsdam than to the heart of Berlin. The bigger of the Wannsee’s lakes (“Grosser Wannsee”) is without doubt the number one all-singing, all-dancing beachside location in Berlin and its buildings are a fine example of the functional New Objectivity style popular in the late Twenties. And with its white sand imported from the Baltic coast, there is plenty of scope for fun in the sun. At 355,000 sq metres, Wannsee beach has space for 30,000 bathers as well as numerous dining and snack options, boat rental, a high-octane playground with a water slide, a range of chairs and strandkorb shelters for rent and, needless to say, a nudist zone.

The yacht-club-rimmed Wannsee Photo: AP/FOTOLIA

Details

Wannseebadweg 25, Wannsee. Take the S1 to Wannsee; the 10-minute walk to the beach is clearly signposted. Entrance: €5.50 (The Wannsee villa which infamously hosted the conference in January 1942 at which senior Nazis decided upon the Final Solution is today a museum: ghwk.de)

Tegeler See

Tegeler See, formed out of a bulge in the Havel river, is located in the north-west part of Berlin, close to Tegel airport. It has a total of seven islands, and in addition to swimming and sunbathing offers steamboat rides, surfing and sailing. Nearby is the splendid Villa Borsig, well worth a visit.

Tegeler See is located in the north-west part of Berlin, close to Tegel airport Photo: AP/FOTOLIA
